 The Democratic Party certainly has made a tangle of the nominating process with its rules that keep the outcome up in the air. I think the biggest reason for this is the proportional allocation of delegates, which in a sense is fair to all candidates but prevents the party from coming up with a clear winner. We Americans are used to winner-take-all elections; we are not used to this kind of system. We would probably be in quite a different situation if we had winner-take-all state primary races. Hillary might actually be on top, because she has won the votes in the big states with the most delegates. But because of the proportional allocation, and the relative closeness of the races, no one candidate can command a substantial lead in delegates. Even when a candidate loses, he or she wins delegates.
